text: A critical role of the <extra_id_0> p75 tumor necrosis factor receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> p75TNF-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) in organ inflammation independent of TNF , <extra_id_0> lymphotoxin alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , or the <extra_id_0> p55TNF-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Despite overwhelming evidence that enhanced production of the <extra_id_0> p75 tumor necrosis factor receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> p75TNF-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) accompanies development of specific human inflammatory pathologies such as multi-organ failure during sepsis , inflammatory liver disease , pancreatitis , respiratory distress syndrome , or AIDS , the function of this receptor remains poorly defined in vivo .

text: We show here that at levels relevant to human disease , production of the human <extra_id_0> p75TNF-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in transgenic mice results in a severe inflammatory syndrome involving mainly the pancreas , liver , kidney , and lung , and characterized by constitutively increased NF-kappaB activity in the peripheral blood mononuclear cell compartment .

This process is shown to evolve independently of the presence of TNF , <extra_id_0> lymphotoxin alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , or the <extra_id_0> p55TNF-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , although coexpression of a human TNF transgene accelerated pathology .

These results establish an independent role for enhanced <extra_id_0> p75TNF-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production in the pathogenesis of inflammatory disease and implicate the direct involvement of this receptor in a wide range of human inflammatory pathologies .
